00001 #ifndef LATTICE_H
00002 #define LATTICE_H
00003 
00004 #include "CallGraphTraverse.h"
00005 #include "variables.h"
00006 #include <string>
00007 #include <map>
00008 
00009 class Lattice : public printable
00010 {
00011         public:
00012         // initializes this Lattice to its default state, if it is not already initialized
00013         virtual void initialize()=0;
00014         // returns a copy/clone of this lattice: TODO rename it to clone, avoid name confusing with copy(Lattice*)
00015         virtual Lattice* copy() const=0;
00016         // overwrites the state of this Lattice with that of that Lattice
00017         virtual void copy(Lattice* that)=0;
00018         
00019         // Called by analyses to replace variables within the current lattice (pointed by this pointer) with new variables.
00020        // This is often needed to propagate lattices across function calls, when dataflow information from 
00021        // the caller/callee needs to be transferred to the callee/calleer.
00022        // The formal arguments/variables will be replaced with actual arguments, or vice versa.
00023        //
00024         // varNameMap - a read-only map containing information for all variable names that have changed, 
00025        //              in each mapping pair, pair->first is the old variable and pair->second is the new variable
00026        //              This map is used to update variables within the current lattice.
00027         // func - the function that the copy Lattice will now be associated with
00028        //
00029        // However, if this lattice maintains any information on a per-variable basis, these per-variable mappings 
00030        // must be converted from the current set of variables to another set. 
00031        //
00032         // We do not force child classes to define their own versions of this function since not all
00033         //    Lattices have per-variable information.
00034        //
00035         virtual void remapVars(const std::map<varID, varID>& varNameMap, const Function& newFunc) {} 
00036         
00037         // Called by analyses to copy over from the that Lattice dataflow information into this Lattice.
00038         // that contains data for a set of variables.
00039        // This function must overwrite the state of just those variables, while leaving its state for other 
00040        // variables alone.
00041        //
00042         // We do not force child classes to define their own versions of this function since not all
00043         //    Lattices have per-variable information.
00044         virtual void incorporateVars(Lattice* that) {}
00045         
00046        // A lattice (this lattice) may contain more information than what is relevant to a given expr. 
00047        // This function will create a new, potentially smaller, lattice for a given expr.
00048         // to describes the information known within this lattice
00049         // about the given expression. 
00050        
00051        // By default this could be the entire lattice or any portion of it.
00052        // 
00053        // For example, a live variable lattice may contain a set of live variables. But only one live variable
00054        // may relevant to a given expression. This function will create a new lattice containing only a single
00055        // variable corresponding to the input expression.
00056        //
00057         // Another example, a lattice that maintains lattices for different known variables and expression will 
00058         // return a lattice for the given expression. Similarly, a lattice that keeps track of constraints
00059         // on values of variables and expressions will return the portion of the lattice that relates to
00060         // the given expression. 
00061        // 
00062         // It is legal for this function to return NULL or an empty lattice if no information is available.
00063         // The function's caller is responsible for deallocating the returned object
00064        //
00065        // TODO: this function name really does not refect what it does. 
00066        // A better name: Lattice * createRelevantLattice(SgExpression* expr)
00067         virtual Lattice* project(SgExpression* expr) { return copy(); }
00068         
00069        // Cherry pick the lattice information which is relevant to expr from exprState, and
00070        // merge the picked information into this lattice. 
00071         // Parameters and return:
00072        // - expr: the expression in question
00073        // - exprState: a lattice which may or may NOT have information about expr.
00074        // - Return true if this lattice is changed by this process. 
00075        // 
00076         // The inverse of project(). The call is provided with an expression and a Lattice that describes
00077         // the dataflow state that relates to expression. This Lattice must be of the same type as the lattice
00078         // returned by project(). unProject() must incorporate this dataflow state into the overall state it holds.
00079         // Call must make an internal copy of the passed-in lattice and the caller is responsible for deallocating it.
00080         // Returns true if this causes this to change and false otherwise.
00081        //
00082        // TODO: the semantics of this function is not the exact inverse of project()
00083        // TODO: a better name: bool meetRelevantLattice (SgExpression* expr, Lattice* exprState);
00084         virtual bool unProject(SgExpression* expr, Lattice* exprState) { return meetUpdate(exprState); }
00085         
00086         // computes the meet of this lattice and that lattice and saves the result in this lattice
00087         // returns true if this causes this lattice to change and false otherwise
00088         virtual bool meetUpdate(Lattice* that)=0;
00089        
00090         // computes the meet of this and that and returns the result
00091         //virtual Lattice* meet(Lattice* that)=0;
00092        
00094         virtual bool finiteLattice()=0;
00095         
00096        // Equal operator: note the pointer type of that lattice
00097         virtual bool operator==(Lattice* that) /*const*/=0;
00098         bool operator!=(Lattice* that) {
00099                 return !(*this == that);
00100         }
00101         bool operator==(Lattice& that) {
00102                 return *this == &that;
00103         }
00104         bool operator!=(Lattice& that) {
00105                 return !(*this == that);
00106         }
00107         
00108         // Functions used to inform this lattice that a given variable is now in use (e.g. a variable has entered 
00109         //    scope or an expression is being analyzed) or is no longer in use (e.g. a variable has exited scope or
00110         //    an expression or variable is dead).
00111         // It is assumed that a newly-added variable has not been added before and that a variable that is being
00112         //    removed was previously added
00113         /*virtual void addVar(varID var)=0;
00114         virtual void remVar(varID var)=0;*/
00115                         
00116         // The string that represents this object
00117         // If indent!="", every line of this string must be prefixed by indent
00118         // The last character of the returned string should not be '\n', even if it is a multi-line string.
00119         //virtual string str(string indent="") /*const*/=0;
00120 };
00121 
00122 class FiniteLattice : public virtual Lattice
00123 {
00124         public:
00125         bool finiteLattice()
00126         { return true;  }
00127 };
00128 
00129 class InfiniteLattice : public virtual Lattice
00130 {
00131         public:
00132         bool finiteLattice()
00133         { return false; }
00134         
00135         // widens this from that and saves the result in this
00136         // returns true if this causes this to change and false otherwise
00137         virtual bool widenUpdate(InfiniteLattice* that)=0;
00138 };
